body.p: A better asymptotic profile of RosenauBurgers equation Liping Liu **, Ming Mei

p.hi: Department of Mathematical Sciences, University of Alberta, Edmonton, Alberta, Canada

body.p: This paper studies the large-time behavior of the global solutions to the Cauchy problem for the RosenauBurgers (R-B) equation subscript𝑢𝑡subscript𝑢𝑥𝑥𝑥𝑥𝑡𝛼subscript𝑢𝑥𝑥subscriptsuperscript𝑢𝑝1𝑝1𝑥0ut+ux⁢x⁢x⁢x⁢t-α⁢ux⁢x+(up+1/(p+1))x=0u_{t}+u_{xxxxt}-\alpha u_{xx}+(u^{p+1}/(p+1))_{x}=0. By the variable scaling method, we discover that the solution of the nonlinear parabolic equation subscript𝑢𝑡𝛼subscript𝑢𝑥𝑥subscriptsuperscript𝑢𝑝1𝑝1𝑥0ut-α⁢ux⁢x+(up+1/(p+1))x=0u_{t}-\alpha u_{xx}+(u^{p+1}/(p+1))_{x}=0 is a better asymptotic profile of the R-B equation. The convergence rates of the R-B equation to the asymptotic profile have been developed by the Fourier transform method with energy estimates. This result is better than the previous work 12 with zero as the asymptotic behavior. Furthermore, the numerical simulations on several test examples are discussed, and the numerical results confirm our theoretical results. ©2002 Elsevier Science Inc. All rights reserved.
Keywords: Rosenau-Burgers equation; Asymptotic profile; Convergence rates
In this paper, we investigate the asymptotic behavior of the solution for the Rosenau-Burgers equation (R-B) in the form
where 𝛼α\alpha is any given constant, 𝑝1p≥1p\geq 1 is integer.

Eq. (1.1) with 𝛼0α=0\alpha=0 is called as the Rosenau equation proposed by Rosenau 3 for treating the dynamics of dense discrete systems in order to overcome the shortenings by the KdVKdV\mathrm{K}\mathrm{d}\mathrm{V} equation, since the KdVKdV\mathrm{K}\mathrm{d}\mathrm{V} equation describes unidi- mensional propagation of waves, but wave-wave and wave-wall interactions cannot be treated by it. Such a model were studied by Park 4 and by Chung and Ha 5 for the global existence of the solution to the IBVP. Eq. (1.1) with 𝛼0α>0\alpha>0 is called the R-B equation and somehow corresponds to the KdVBKdV-B\mathrm{K}\mathrm{d}\mathrm{V}-\mathrm{B} equation and the BBM-B equation, but it is given neither by Rosenau nor by Burgers. The Rosenau equation with the dissipative term 𝛼subscript𝑢𝑥𝑥-α⁢ux⁢x-\alpha u_{xx}, or say, the RBR-B\mathrm{R}-\mathrm{B} equation arises in some natural phenomena as for example, in bore propagation and in water waves.
The asymptotic behavior of the solution for the Cauchy problem (1.1) is studied in 12. Where, it is proved that the solution 𝑢𝑥𝑡u⁢(x,t)u(x,\ t) converges to 00 as fast as follows:
for all 𝑡0t≥0t\geq 0 if superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑢0𝑥differential-d𝑥0∫-∞∞u0⁢(x)⁢dx≠0\displaystyle\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}u_{0}(x)\mathrm{d}x\neq 0
and
for all 𝑡0t≥0t\geq 0 if superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑢0𝑥differential-d𝑥0∫-∞∞u0⁢(x)⁢dx=0.\displaystyle\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}u_{0}(x)\mathrm{d}x=0.

In all the previous works, 00 is considered as the asymptotic state of the solution 𝑢𝑥𝑡u⁢(x,t)u(x,\ t) for the R-B equation. In this study, inspired by the works 67 on the BBM-B equations, we obtain a better asymptotic profile, i.e. a solution of its corresponding nonlinear parabolic equation, for the R-B equation. Further- more, it is proved that the convergence to the asymptotic profile is faster than that to the zero.

For simplicity we introduce some notations. Corollary 2.3.Under the assumptions in Theorem 2.2, for2𝑞2≤q≤∞2\leq q\leq\infty, it follows:

1. In the case superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑢0𝑥differential-d𝑥0∫-∞∞u0⁢(x)⁢dx≠0\displaystyle\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}u_{0}(x)\mathrm{d}x\neq 0 but superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑢0𝑥subscript𝜃0𝑥differential-d𝑥0∫-∞∞(u0⁢(x)-θ0⁢(x))⁢dx=0\displaystyle\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}(u_{0}(x)-\theta_{0}(x))\mathrm{d}x=0, our decay rates to the diffusion wave 𝜃𝑥𝑡θ⁢(x,t)\theta(x,\ t) are much better than that to the zero in 12. This means that the solution 𝜃𝑥𝑡θ⁢(x,t)\theta(x,\ t) of the nonlinear parabolic Eq. (2.3) is a better asymptotic profile of the R-B solution 𝑢𝑥𝑡u⁢(x,t)u(x,\ t) than the zero.

2. In case 𝑝1p=1p=1, it seems that the rate is not sufficient, and the optimal rate could be superscript1𝑡1(1+t)-1(1+t)^{-1} as in the case 𝑝2p≥2p\geq 2. Our numerical simulation in Section 4 confirms it too. We expect more contributions on this problem.

Once Theorem 3.1 is proved, by 𝑢𝑥𝑡𝜃𝑥𝑡subscript𝑣𝑥𝑥𝑡u⁢(x,t)-θ⁢(x,t)=vx⁢(x,t)u(x,\ t)-\theta(x,\ t)=v_{x}(x,\ t) , it is easy to prove our main theorem, i.e. Theorem 2.2. Therefore, in the rest of this section, our main goal is to prove Theorem 3.1. Before we prove this theorem, we state several needed lemmas.

Proof of Theorem 3.1. Rewriting (3.7) as the operational form 𝑣𝑆𝑣v=S⁢vv=Sv. We need to prove that there exists the positive constant subscript𝛿1δ1\delta_{1} such that the operator 𝑆SS is a contraction mapping from superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑝subscript𝛿1Xpδ1X_{p}^{\delta_{1}} into superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑝subscript𝛿1Xpδ1.X_{p}^{\delta_{1}}.

Step 1. To prove that𝑆SSmapssuperscriptsubscript𝑋𝑝𝛿XpδX_{p}^{\delta}into itself For any subscript𝑣1𝑥𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑝𝛿v1⁢(x,t)∈Xpδv_{1}(x,\ t)\in X_{p}^{\delta} and de- noting 𝑣𝑆subscript𝑣1v=S⁢v1v=Sv_{1}, we will prove 𝑣superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑝𝛿v∈Xpδv\in X_{p}^{\delta} for some small 𝛿0δ>0\delta>0. Thus, we proved :𝑆→superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑝𝛿superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑝𝛿S:Xpδ→XpδS:X_{p}^{\delta}\rightarrow X_{p}^{\delta} for some small 𝛿subscript𝛿2δ<δ2.\delta<\delta_{2}.

Step 2. To prove that𝑆SSis a contraction insuperscriptsubscript𝑋𝑝𝛿XpδX_{p}^{\delta}. Suppose that subscript𝑣1𝑥𝑡v1⁢(x,t)v_{1}(x,\ t) , fragmentssubscript𝑣2fragments(x,t)superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑝𝛿fragments(δsubscript𝛿2)v2(x,t)∈Xpδ(δ<δ2)v_{2}(x,\ t)\in X_{p}^{\delta}(\delta<\delta_{2}) . By (3.7),
for 𝑗0j=0j=0, 1, 2 and 𝑝1p≥1p\geq 1. First, we estimate subscriptnorm𝑆subscript𝑣1𝑆subscript𝑣2superscript𝐿2∥S⁢v1-S⁢v2∥L2.\|Sv_{1}-Sv_{2}\|_{L^{2}}.

m:math.alttext: \begin{split}\displaystyle\int_{0}^{t}\|\frac{1}{2\pi}\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}% \mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i}\xi x}\frac{\mathrm{e}^{-B(\xi)(t-s)}}{1+\xi^{4}}(F_{p}% \hat{(v_{1}})(\xi,\ s)-F_{p}\hat{(v_{2}})(\xi,\ s))\mathrm{d}\xi\|_{L^{2}}% \mathrm{d}s\\ \displaystyle=\int_{0}^{t}\|\frac{\mathrm{e}^{-B(\xi)(t-s)}}{1+\xi^{4}}(F_{p}% \hat{(v_{1}})(\xi,\ s)-F_{p}\hat{(v_{2}})(\xi,\ s))\|_{L^{2}}\mathrm{d}s\\ \displaystyle=\int_{0}^{t}(\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\frac{\mathrm{e}^{-2B(\xi)(t% -s)}}{(1+\xi^{4})^{2}}|F_{p}\hat{(v_{1}})(\xi,\ s)-F_{p}\hat{(v_{2}})(\xi,\ s)% |^{2}\mathrm{d}\xi)^{1/2}\mathrm{d}s\\ \displaystyle\leq\int_{0}^{t}\sup_{\xi\in\mathrm{R}}|F_{p}\hat{(v_{1}})(\xi,\ % s)-F_{p}\hat{(v_{2}})(\xi,\ s)|(\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\frac{\mathrm{e}^{-2B(% \xi)(t-s)}}{(1+\xi^{4})^{2}}\mathrm{d}\xi)^{1/2}\mathrm{d}s.\end{split}

body.p: Using Lemmas 3.2, 3.3 and 3.6, we obtain
Namely, we obtain

Using Lemmas 3.2, 3.3 and 3.6, we can similarly estimate subscriptnormsubscript𝑥𝑆subscript𝑣1𝑆subscript𝑣2superscript𝐿2∥∂x⁡(S⁢v1-S⁢v2)∥L2\|\partial_{x}(Sv_{1}-Sv_{2})\|_{L^{2}} and subscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝑥2𝑆subscript𝑣1𝑆subscript𝑣2superscript𝐿2∥∂x2⁡(S⁢v1-S⁢v2)∥L2\|\partial_{x}^{2}(Sv_{1}-Sv_{2})\|_{L^{2}} as follows:
and
With (3.50)-(3.52) , we proved that, for some constant subscript𝐶1C1,C_{1},

Choose 𝛿subscript𝛿31𝑛subscript𝐶1δ≤δ3<1/n⁢C1\delta\leq\delta_{3}<1/nC_{1} with 𝑛2subscript𝐶1 2n=max⁡{2/C1, 2}n=\displaystyle\max\{2/C_{1},\ 2\}, then for formulae-sequence𝜂subscript𝛿3𝑀subscript𝑣1subscript𝛿3η<δ3,M⁢(v1)<δ3\eta<\delta_{3},M(v_{1})<\delta_{3} and 𝑀subscript𝑣2subscript𝛿3M⁢(v2)<δ3M(v_{2})<\delta_{3}, we have
That is 𝑆SS : →superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑝𝛿superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑝𝛿Xpδ→XpδX_{p}^{\delta}\rightarrow X_{p}^{\delta} is contracting for some small 𝛿subscript𝛿3δ<δ3.\delta<\delta_{3}.

By Steps 1 and 2, let subscript𝛿1subscript𝛿2subscript𝛿3δ1<min⁡{δ2,δ3}\displaystyle\delta_{1}<\min\{\delta_{2},\ \delta_{3}\}, we have proved that the operator 𝑆SS is contracting from superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑝subscript𝛿1Xpδ1X_{p}^{\delta_{1}} to superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑝subscript𝛿1Xpδ1X_{p}^{\delta_{1}}. By Banach’s fixed point theorem, 𝑆SS has a unique fixed point 𝑣𝑥𝑡v⁢(x,t)v(x,\ t) in superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑝subscript𝛿1Xpδ1X_{p}^{\delta_{1}}. Thus, the integral equation has a unique global so- lution formulae-sequence𝑣𝑥𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑝subscript𝛿1□v⁢(x,t)∈Xpδ1.□v(x,\ t)\in X_{p}^{\delta_{1}}.\square
4. Numerical simulations

In order to confirm the theoretical result in Theorem 2.2, numerical simula- tion has been carried out for cases 𝑝1p=1p=1 and 𝑝3p=3p=3. The applied numerical scheme solving Eqs. (1.1) and (2.3) is the explicit finite difference scheme. For the consideration of the Cauchy problem, we adopt a suitable IBVP for a sufficiently large domain ΩRΩ⊂R\Omega\subset\mathrm{R} with zero Neumann boundary in stead of the original IVP. Let 𝜃𝑥𝑡θ⁢(x,t)\theta(x,\ t) and 𝑢𝑥𝑡u⁢(x,t)u(x,\ t) denote the solutions of the parabolic equation and the R-B equation, respectively. Consider the initial condition subscript𝜃0𝑥θ0⁢(x)\theta_{0}(x) and subscript𝑢0𝑡u0⁢(t)u_{0}(t) as
Thus,
But superscriptsubscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝜃0𝑥subscript𝑢0𝑥differential-d𝑥0∫-∞∞[θ0⁢(x)-u0⁢(x)]⁢dx=0.\displaystyle\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}[\theta_{0}(x)-u_{0}(x)]\mathrm{d}x=0.
For the following discussion, the time-step and the space-step are 0.5 and 1, respectively. We compute the time 𝑡tt from 00 to 20000 for 𝑥Ω2000 2000x∈Ω=[-2000, 2000].x\in\Omega=[-2000,\ 2000].

The solution of the R-B equation for 𝑡absentt∈t\in [2000, 10000] and 𝑥200 200x∈[-200, 200]x\in[-200,\ 200] is displayed in Fig. 1. The grid size used in plotting the graph is Δ𝑥4Δ⁢x=4\Delta x=4 and Δ𝑡100Δ⁢t=100\Delta t=100. The diffusion wave solution of the corresponding nonlinear para- bolic equation is similar to Fig. 1. Fig. 2 shows the difference of these two

solutions: 𝑢𝑥𝑡𝜃𝑥𝑡u⁢(x,t)-θ⁢(x,t)u(x,\ t)-\theta(x,\ t) with the same time and space intervals, and the same grid as in Fig. 1. Comparing Figs. 1 and 2, noticing the different scales in the 𝑍ZZ-axes, we discover that the value of 𝑢𝑥𝑡𝜃𝑥𝑡u⁢(x,t)-θ⁢(x,t)u(x,\ t)-\theta(x,\ t) is much smaller than

𝑢𝑥𝑡Ou⁢(x,t)-Ou(x,\ t)-\mathrm{O}. Thus, we expect that 𝑢𝑥𝑡u⁢(x,t)u(x,\ t) approaches to 𝜃𝑥𝑡θ⁢(x,t)\theta(x,\ t) much faster than it does to zero. Since 𝑢𝑥𝑡u⁢(x,t)u(x,\ t) , 𝜃𝑥𝑡θ⁢(x,t)\theta(x,\ t) and 𝑢𝑥𝑡𝜃𝑥𝑡u⁢(x,t)-θ⁢(x,t)u(x,\ t)-\theta(x,\ t) approach to zero when 𝑥xx approaches to infinity, subscriptnorm𝑢𝑡superscript𝐿subscriptnorm𝜃𝑡superscript𝐿∥u⁢(t)∥L∞,∥θ⁢(t)∥L∞\|u(t)\|_{L^{\infty}},\|\theta(t)\|_{L^{\infty}} and subscriptnorm𝑢𝜃𝑡superscript𝐿∥(u-θ)⁢(t)∥L∞\|(u-\theta)(t)\|_{L^{\infty}} can be estimated by fragmentssubscript𝑥Ω|ufragments(x,tsubscript𝑥Ω|θfragments(x,t)|maxx∈Ω|u(x,tmaxx∈Ω|θ(x,t)|\displaystyle\max_{x\in\Omega}|u(x,\ t\ \max_{x\in\Omega}|\theta(x,\ t)| and fragmentssubscript𝑥Ω|ufragments(x,t)θfragments(x,tmaxx∈Ω|u(x,t)-θ(x,t\displaystyle\max_{x\in\Omega}|u(x,\ t)-\theta(x,t respectively. Figs. 3, 4, 6 present the decay rates for 𝑢𝑥𝑡u⁢(x,t)u(x,\ t) , 𝜃𝑥𝑡θ⁢(x,t)\theta(x,\ t) and 𝑢𝑥𝑡𝜃𝑥𝑡u⁢(x,t)-θ⁢(x,t)u(x,\ t)-\theta(x,\ t) . The grid size used in these figures is Δ𝑡100Δ⁢t=100.\Delta t=100.

Fig. 3(a) shows the ratio subscript𝐹𝜃𝑡subscriptnorm𝜃𝑡superscript𝐿superscript1𝑡12Fθ⁢(t)=∥θ⁢(t)∥L∞/(1+t)-1/2F_{\theta}(t)=\|\theta(t)\|_{L^{\infty}}/(1+t)^{-1/2}. For the time 𝑡tt from →𝑡t→∞,t\rightarrow\infty,where Cfragments10normal-,000to20normal-,000normal-,0.6992normal-.10,000to20,000,=0.6992.10,000\mathrm{t}\mathrm{o}20,000,=0.6992. Thus,wehavesubscriptnorm𝜃𝑡superscript𝐿𝐶superscript1𝑡1absent:wehave⁢∥θ⁢(t)∥L∞=C⁢(1+t)-1⁣/:,\mathrm{w}\mathrm{e}\mathrm{h}\mathrm{a}\mathrm{v}\mathrm{e}\|\theta(t)\|_{L^{% \infty}}=C(1+t)^{-1/:},which conweoon-weo\mathrm{o}\mathrm{n}-\mathrm{w}\mathrm{e}\mathrm{o}btain almost astraight 1ineine.\mathrm{i}\mathrm{n}\mathrm{e}.This i→mp1iessubscript𝐹𝜃𝑡𝐶whenmp1ies⁢Fθ⁢(t)→C⁢when\mathrm{m}\mathrm{p}1\mathrm{i}\mathrm{e}\mathrm{s}F_{\theta}(t)\rightarrow C% \mathrm{w}\mathrm{h}\mathrm{e}\mathrm{n} firms the theoretical assertion: subscriptnorm𝜃𝑡superscript𝐿𝐶superscript1𝑡12∥θ⁢(t)∥L∞≤C⁢(1+t)-1/2\|\theta(t)\|_{L^{\infty}}\leq C(1+t)^{-1/2}. Similar result can be found for subscriptnorm𝑢𝑡superscript𝐿∥u⁢(t)∥L∞\|u(t)\|_{L^{\infty}} from the ratio subscript𝐹𝑢𝑡subscriptnorm𝜃𝑡superscript𝐿superscript1𝑡12Fu⁢(t)=∥θ⁢(t)∥L∞/(1+t)-1/2F_{u}(t)=\|\theta(t)\|_{L^{\infty}}/(1+t)^{-1/2} shown in Fig. 3(b).

Our main interest is the decay rate of the difference 𝑢𝑥𝑡𝜃𝑥𝑡u⁢(x,t)-θ⁢(x,t)u(x,\ t)-\theta(x,\ t) . The ratio subscript𝐹𝑠𝑡subscriptnorm𝑢𝜃𝑡superscript𝐿superscript1𝑡78Fs⁢(t)=∥(u-θ)⁢(t)∥L∞/(1+t)-7/8F_{s}(t)=\|(u-\theta)(t)\|_{L^{\infty}}/(1+t)^{-7/8} is shown in Fig. 4(a), where the ratio value keeps decreasing as 𝑡tt increases. This numerical result shows that subscriptnorm𝑢𝜃𝑡superscript𝐿∥(u-θ)⁢(t)∥L∞\|(u-\theta)(t)\|_{L^{\infty}}

decays faster than the function superscript1𝑡78(1+t)-7/8(1+t)^{-7/8}. In fact, it is found that subscriptnorm𝑢𝜃𝑡superscript𝐿∥(u-θ)⁢(t)∥L∞\|(u-\theta)(t)\|_{L^{\infty}} decays to zero with the same rate as superscript1𝑡0.998(1+t)-0.998(1+t)^{-0.998}, which is shown in Fig. 4(b). Thus, in this example, subscriptnorm𝑢𝜃𝑡superscript𝐿𝐶superscript1𝑡0.998∥(u-θ)⁢(t)∥L∞=C⁢(1+t)-0.998\|(u-\theta)(t)\|_{L^{\infty}}=C(1+t)^{-0.998} with 𝐶absentC=C= 0.2168. Several other initial conditions have been considered. However, we have not found any example such that subscriptnorm𝑢𝜃𝑡superscript𝐿𝐶superscript1𝑡78𝜎∥(u-θ)⁢(t)∥L∞=C⁢(1+t)-7/8+σ\|(u-\theta)(t)\|_{L^{\infty}}=C(1+t)^{-7/8+\sigma} (with fragmentsσ0)σ>0)\sigma>0) . This may imply that our theoretical result is not optimal. Inspired by Fig. 4(b), it seems that subscriptnorm𝑢𝜃𝑡superscript𝐿𝐶superscript1𝑡1∥(u-θ)⁢(t)∥L∞=C⁢(1+t)-1\|(u-\theta)(t)\|_{L^{\infty}}=C(1+t)^{-1}, whose theoretical proof still remains open.

The theoretical result for cases 𝑝2p≥2p\geq 2 are the same, numerically we only present the results for 𝑝3p=3p=3. For the considered initial condition, the decay rates of 𝑢𝑥𝑡u⁢(x,t)u(x,\ t) and 𝜃𝑥𝑡θ⁢(x,t)\theta(x,\ t) are displayed in Fig. 5(a) and (b), respectively. In Fig. 6, as →𝑡t→∞t\rightarrow\infty, the ratio line of subscriptnorm𝑢𝜃𝑡superscript𝐿superscript1𝑡1∥(u-θ)⁢(t)∥L∞/(1+t)-1\|(u-\theta)(t)\|_{L^{\infty}}/(1+t)^{-1} seems to be a con- stant line, implying →subscriptnorm𝑢𝜃𝑡superscript𝐿superscript1𝑡1𝐶∥(u-θ)⁢(t)∥L∞/(1+t)-1→C\|(u-\theta)(t)\|_{L^{\infty}}/(1+t)^{-1}\rightarrow C, where 𝐶0.0675C=0.0675C=0.0675. Hence, subscriptnorm𝑢𝜃𝑡superscript𝐿∥(u-θ)⁢(t)∥L∞\|(u-\theta)(t)\|_{L^{\infty}} decays as fast as the function superscript1𝑡1(1+t)-1(1+t)^{-1} does, confirming our theoretical result.
Acknowledgements
The first author would like to acknowledge the strong support and valuable suggestions received from her supervisor Professor Yau-Shu Wong.
